elements.name: Survey21 Introduction
elements.html:
Welcome to the Military Triage Delegation Experiment. Here you will have the chance to review the decisions of other medical professionals in difficult triage scenarios to assess whether you would delegate a triage situation in the future to those decision makers.

Each scenario is presented followed by how two different medics carried out their assessment and treatment separately for that situation. Their actions are listed in the order they performed them.

Each medic vignette is then followed by a few questions to assess how you perceived the medic’s decision-making style.

While you work your way through each vignette imagine you have seen a lot of other observations of this medic, and the behavior you see here is typical for how they behave.

Some of the scenarios will seem familiar to you. Please note that there may be differences in the details of the situation you saw and the one you will be evaluating. Specifically, please pay careful attention to what information is revealed to the decision maker, and consider their actions only with respect to the information they were given. Do not consider any information from your experience that might be different or contradictory.

The survey should take about 30 minutes to complete. Thank you for your participation.

elements.name: Note
elements.html:
Note that in some scenarios, there are buttons that expand/select the information for the medic and the patients.

Note that you can hit the "previous" button if you want to go back to any part of the survey.

elements.title: Adept Submarine Scenario: Medic-AD1
elements.name: Adept Submarine Scenario: Medic-AD1
actions: Requests the electrician’s mate brought first
Walks to the patients instead
Update: Learns that the electrician’s mate caused the accident
Switches to treat the other sailor first
Update: Learns that both sailors were horsing around and caused the accident
Update: A third patient is discovered with electrical shock and a pre-existing condition
Leaves the two original patients to treat the new patient
elements.explanation: I considered who was to blame for the situation
situation: The medic on a submarine responded to a bad electrical accident. The Electrician Chief required one of the Electrician’s mates to work during their sleep cycle (coming off duty) to repair an electrical issue with the treadmill. A sailor who had been bugging the chief about getting it fixed for his own use was hanging around waiting for it to be done. During the repair, there was a small electrical fire and both sailors were seriously injured. They are reported to have similar injuries. Crew mates are bringing the patients the medic in the wardroom. The corridor is tight and they can only bring one at a time.

patients.name: Patient-I
patients.description: Male submarine sailor (the Electrician’s Mate), major electrical burns on right side and an ear bleed.

patients.name: Patient-J
patients.description: Male submarine sailor (the sailor who wanted the treadmill repaired), major electrical burns on right side and an ear bleed.

Update: Learns that both sailors were horsing around and caused the accident
Update: A third patient is discovered with electrical shock and a pre-existing condition

Adept Jungle Scenario: Medic-AD3
elements.name: Adept Jungle Scenario: Medic-AD3
actions: Treats the patient closer to the IED first (Patient K)
Update: Learns that Patient K poked at the IED and ignored a US soldier who yelled at him to leave it alone
Switch to treat Patient L
Update: Learns that Patient K tried to lure US soldiers to the explosion
Evacuates Patient L in the one available transport option
elements.explanation: I considered who was to blame for the situation.
situation: A medic on a security patrol encountered a serious accident potentially from an IED explosion. They were told that a civilian found what looked like it might be an IED, reported it to authorities, and then against advice, went back and triggered accidental detonation while taking a closer look. There are two civilian patients, one closer to what looks like the IED materials and one further away on a path. The patient who is closer to the IED materials seems to be more seriously injured.

patients.name: Patient-K
patients.description: Asian male civilian, closer to the IED. Has burns and a puncture wound

patients.name: Patient-L
patients.description: Asian male civilian, further from the IED. Has fracture

Adept Desert Scenario: Medic-AD5
elements.name: Adept Desert Scenario: Medic-AD5
actions: Decides en route to evacuate the local soldier (Patient N)
Update: Learns that Patient M saved the whole group from an ambush
Changes decision, plans to evacuate the US soldier (Patient M)
Update: Learns that Patient M was going to hurt his own unit leader
Changes decision, evacuates the local soldier (Patient N)
elements.explanation: I considered the past actions of the casualties.

supplies.type: The helicopter has one slot for a serious injury.

The hospital is a military facility that serves both US and local forces. The patient who isn’t transported by helicopter will have to go by slower ground vehicle which could potentially aggravate their injury and risk adverse medical consequences.

situation: A medic on a helicopter en route to a remote location learns that a US soldier and a local soldier are both seriously injured. According to the report, the US soldier started a fight with another US soldier, and the local soldier tried to de-escalate. They were both seriously injured because in the struggle, they fell against a wall of a damaged building, and the wall collapsed on them.

patients.name: Patient-M
patients.description: Male US soldier, broken right shoulder

patients.name: Patient-N
patients.description: Male local soldier, broken right shoulder

Adept Urban Scenario: Medic-AD7
elements.name: Adept Urban Scenario: Medic-AD7
actions: Starts treating Patient P (not dressed in black)
Update: Hears from a bystander that Patient O was the shooter and Patient P the victim
Continues treating Patient P (victim)
Update: Patient P’s condition deteriorates, indicating unlikely to survive transport
Transports Patient P (victim) to the hospital
elements.explanation: I considered who was to blame for the situation

supplies.type: The local civilian hospital does not have significant surgical capabilities

There is not time to treat both patients, and both are likely to die without treatment. The civilian in black clothes has injuries that are definitely treatable, but the other civilian may die even if treated, due to the limited capabilities of the local hospital.

situation: The medic is on the scene after there was some kind of shooting between civilians.

patients.name: Patient-O
patients.description: Male civilian, all black clothing, shot in right shoulder and arm

patients.name: Patient-P
patients.description: Male civilian, shot in right shoulder, arm, and chest

Transports Patient O (shooter) to the hospital
elements.explanation: I prioritized the person who had the more survivable injury.
